results.title: The Spag [released version]
results.brief_description: Director Giorgio Mangiamele produced the first examples of multicultural cinema in this country. ‘The Spag’ was shot in the streets of Carlton and tells the story of a newspaper boy working to support his widowed mother; along the way his life is fraught with racism. The film is Neo-Realist in style and makes interesting use of incidental music and post-sync dubbed dialogue track; a dog’s bark is even mimicked by an actor’s voice. Stars the young Terry Donovan.

results.title: Black Sunday
results.brief_description: Depicts the devastation caused by the notorious ‘Black Sunday’ bushfires of 1926, that wiped out the south-east of Victoria.

results.title: Hassles
results.creator_credit: Ross Simmons, Jason Ollivier, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: One of three films as part of the National Drug Education Program which takes an in-depth view of drug addiction in the day-to-day lives of ordinary people. The central character is a teenage boy who found the courage to give up heavy marijuana smoking. His motive was simply the challenge itself, but the price of his success is rejection by his lifelong friends and associates who accuse him of simply substituting one source of stimulation for another. Photography by Dean Semler. (See also ‘Thirst’ [012683] and ‘All in the same boat’ [012758].)

results.title: The Gallery
results.creator_credit: Phillip Mark-Law, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: This film about the National Gallery of Victoria is beautifully conceived and deserves its many film festival awards. Kerry Brown (editor) and Graham Chase (cinematographer) provide stunning contrasts, dissolves and cut images of the architectural design and art holdings. The Great Hall with its lead light ceiling and water window is also featured. These images are complimented by Leslie Dempsey’s impressive electronic score. This film is carefully composed without voice-over narration. Winner of top awards at film festivals in Cork, Brussels, San Francisco, Melbourne and Chicago. Edited by Graham Chase. No spoken commentary.

results.title: Travellin' round
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Richard Mason, Tourism Australia and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A girl and a boy in a Landrover, a motorcyclist and a continent. These are the most essential ingredients of a travel film with a difference, showing the beauties and splendours of Australia. Featuring Tom Burstall, Adam Plate, Ingrid Tantu, Lloyd Sutton, Susan Hannaford. Music and lyrics by Michael Carlos and Judy Henderson.

results.title: Way to a New World
results.creator_credit: Richard Mason, Maslyn Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The old and the new in Papua New Guinea. The traditional way of life in the villages; trade with other villages, the belief in magic, raising garden crops, management of village affairs by the old men in secret, feasts and sing-sings, the initiation of the young men. The new ways; opportunities for education, improved health and child welfare, the introduction of cash crops and native cooperation associations, the formation of elected Local Government Councils.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Mason, Maslyn Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board

results.title: The Valley is ours
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes, John Heyer and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This classic documentary celebrates the variety of activities the Murray River and the surrounding district sustains: from agriculture to timber, fishing to mining, fruit picking to shipbuilding. There is a special focus on the optimistic spirit of the people of the region as they overcome problems of erosion, bushfire and drought and makes a plea for further development, arguing that at least another million people could find happy homes in this fertile territory.

results.title: Three To Go: Toula
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Part of a trilogy concerning the problems of young people in Australia. Toula is a girl in a Greek migrant family living in a Greek community in Sydney. She wants desperately to be a young, modern Australian, but she loves her parents and they demand a different way of life. In spite of family difference, gradually Toula and her brother establish a blend of Greek and Australian, bi-lingual and bi-social, which provides a certain amount of satisfaction for all concerned.

results.title: Surf Beach
results.creator_credit: Bern Gandy, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Beaches are part of the Australian way of life. Every year masses flock to the long white beaches to enjoy the sun and the surf; the thrill of riding a wave can be experienced by all on rubber floats, fibre glass malibous, or body surfing. Life saving clubs originating in Sydney and numbering some 230, play an important role in patrolling the beaches and carrying out rescue. Competitive Surf Carnivals provide exciting entertainment.

results.title: The Splendour and the Peaks
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Eric Thompson, Tasmanian Government Film Unit, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The Freycinet and Mount Field National Parks in Tasmania. Family parties and bushwalkers visit the Freycinet Peninsular where the red granite peaks of the Hazards dominate the sheltered waters of Coles Bay. From the summit of the highest peak, Mt Amos, there is a magnificent view of Wineglass Bay. At Mt Field we find the Russell Falls, Lake Dobson, Lake Seal, the towering dolerite columns of the watcher, and beautiful trees, birds and mosses to delight the visitor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Rogers, Eric Thompson, Tasmanian Government Film Unit, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board
